content.description: Sit start matched on a slightly diagonal undercling feature 3 feet off the ground. Make a hard pull on to the wall using good footholds and make a hard move or two up to larger holds before pulling up and over the angle change on to some smooth rock with some nice jugs for the slab top out.
content.protection: 1 pad. The large feature used for the first few moves looks like it is detached, but it seems to be lodged and sturdy. It wasn't moving when 4 of us did the problem.
content.location: This problem is located in the middle of East face. Starting on a mound-like feature in the ground. The starting underclings are fairly obvious.

content.description:
The mega-classic line of this boulder, and probably one of the best lines at Clough. Incredible movement and marginal holds finished with a tough mantle. This is the sit start to The Lone Wolf.  

  Start sitting low with fantastic heel toe cam, right hand on the bottom of the arete, left under you're heel and right foot smeared. Levitate up to the arete, make a tough match, then decipher the sequence you'll need to get to the top without being too pumped for the scary mantle. Top out and howl at the moon.
content.protection: At least 2 pads, 3 is really recommended. 1 pad would mean you'd have no protection except for on the last 2 moves.
content.location: On the Lone Wolf Boulder, this is the first arete you see when you approach the boulder.

content.description:
The stand for Tears Of A Lone Wolf. This is a sick line on it's own though too.  

  On the right arete, start about halfway up the arete on some little nubbins about 6' up. Figure out how to get to the peak of the boulder using power and big moves, or small movement and lots of beta. Once you get to the peak, commit to a tough top out that'll get your blood pumping from the bad landing.
content.protection: 2 pads, 1 for the beginning, and 1 to cover the rock under the topout. A spotter would be nice but I never had one.
content.location: In the south end boulders, on the Lone Wolf Boulder. This is the first arete you see when approaching the boulder.

content.description: Another great slopey traverse. Start down low on the left arete (to the left/below the crack) and traverse the lip, fight the pump because the crux comes at the top. Make a tough move to the top of the peak and pull a hard topout.
content.protection: 2 pads. 1 for the traverse and one to cover the rock at the bottom of the top out. A spotter is also nice.
content.location: The Lone Wolf boulder at the South End, this is the left arete and it shares the top out with The Lone Wolf.

content.description:
The alternative start for Coyotes. This line starts about as low in the crack as possible, makes a handful of very hard moves up the crack that get you pumped for the long traverse and heady topout.  

  Start as low in the crack as possible, traverse the crack to the arete, then finish up Coyotes.  

  The lower portion of this crack is often wet. It's also very fun to start one move further into the crack the from the start of this, as it gives you better feet. This way is probably v4/5.
content.protection: 2 pads. Spotter is nice but not necessary.
content.location: On the Lone Wolf boulder, this climbs the often wet crack next to Coyotes.

content.description: This is a large boulder found within the South Side Area with a few great lines on it. The Jake Perry mega-classic is known as "Tears of a Lone Wolf" and left of that is a brick hard crack with some unique pockets to start with while lying down, this problem is known as "Coyote Killer".
